elements.clean_text:
Graphical abstract

A novel 3D coordination polymer was synthesized in a hydrothermal reaction. The thermal stability and photoluminescence properties of complex have been investigated.     

Abstract

A novel three dimensional (3D) coordination polymer [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  (pydc=pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate, Hpic=picolinic acid) (1) has been synthesized hydrothermally and characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, TG/DTA, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). This compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with cell parameters a =9.3041(13)Å, b =14.216(2)Å, c =10.5401(15)Å, V =1387.72(30)Å3 and Z =4. Complex 1 has a distinct 3D open-framework architecture due to the presence of picolinic ligands, which are converted from 2,5-pydc ligands by in-situ decarboxylation under the hydrothermal conditions. The compound exhibits strong luminescent emissions because of the f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion at room temperature. According to TGA/DTA analysis, the coordination polymer is thermally stable up to ~300°C.

<ce:section-title id="st005">Introduction</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0005" view="all">Over the past decades, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great interest due to their potential applications in research dealing with magnetism, gas storage, luminescence, catalysis, molecular recognition and separation of lanthanide complexes . Hydrothermal synthesis is one of the primary and most practical methods used to produce MOFs, by exploiting the conditions of high temperature and pressure for ligands which are not normally soluble in water at atmospheric pressure. The types of solvents, pH, reactant stoichiometry and reaction temperature all play crucial roles in determining the crystal structures of the MOFs . A multifunctional carboxylic acid is one of the several best choices because of the flexible or rigid conjugate system with different coordination modes and configurations to synthesize lanthanide CPs or MOFs . The 2,3-, 2,4-, 2,5-, 2,6-, 3,4- and 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (pydc) ligands have been extensively used. In particular, 2,5-pydc is good as a ligand for the preparation of new CPs because it more easily coordinates to metal atoms to form an infinite structure since the two carboxyl groups with a 180° angle may be helpful in reducing space hindrance and form rigid frameworks . However, some ligands can easily lose partial carboxyl groups under the hydrothermal conditions, leading to the construction of many of unpredictable complexes. Che et al.’s research reported on the in situ decarboxylation that resulted in quinoline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid losing one 2-position carboxyl group and producing quinoline-3-carboxylic acid to generate 1D CPs . Liu and colleagues found that decarboxylation reactions occurred for 2,5-pydc acids, which transformed into 3-pyridinecarboxylic acids, leading to the formation of unprecedented 3D MOFs . Also, in our previous work, we observed decarboxylation during the synthesis of a complex unlike that of Liu et al. The results showed that the decarboxylation occurred at the 5-carboxylate group rather than the 2-carboxylate group of 2,5-pydc (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0035"></ce:float-anchor>), and produced picolinic acid, which acts as a second ligand together with the main ligand in the coordination environment.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Over the past decades, coordination polymers (CPs) and metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have been of great interest due to their potential applications in research dealing with magnetism, gas storage, luminescence, catalysis, molecular recognition and separation of lanthanide complexes . Hydrothermal synthesis is one of the primary and most practical methods used to produce MOFs, by exploiting the conditions of high temperature and pressure for ligands which are not normally soluble in water at atmospheric pressure. The types of solvents, pH, reactant stoichiometry and reaction temperature all play crucial roles in determining the crystal structures of the MOFs . A multifunctional carboxylic acid is one of the several best choices because of the flexible or rigid conjugate system with different coordination modes and configurations to synthesize lanthanide CPs or MOFs . The 2,3-, 2,4-, 2,5-, 2,6-, 3,4- and 3,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (pydc) ligands have been extensively used. In particular, 2,5-pydc is good as a ligand for the preparation of new CPs because it more easily coordinates to metal atoms to form an infinite structure since the two carboxyl groups with a 180° angle may be helpful in reducing space hindrance and form rigid frameworks . However, some ligands can easily lose partial carboxyl groups under the hydrothermal conditions, leading to the construction of many of unpredictable complexes. Che et al.'s research reported on the in situ decarboxylation that resulted in quinoline-2,3-dicarboxylic acid losing one 2-position carboxyl group and producing quinoline-3-carboxylic acid to generate 1D CPs . Liu and colleagues found that decarboxylation reactions occurred for 2,5-pydc acids, which transformed into 3-pyridinecarboxylic acids, leading to the formation of unprecedented 3D MOFs . Also, in our previous work, we observed decarboxylation during the synthesis of a complex unlike that of Liu et al. The results showed that the decarboxylation occurred at the 5-carboxylate group rather than the 2-carboxylate group of 2,5-pydc ( ), and produced picolinic acid, which acts as a second ligand together with the main ligand in the coordination environment.

elements.content:
<ce:para id="p0010" view="all">In this study, we chose the ligand 2,5-pydc because of its aforementioned features. Consequently we can report the synthesis and crystal structure of a novel samarium(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(pic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pydc)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>), with an unprecedented coordination mode of 2,5-pydc. The thermal stability and luminescence property of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> is also presented. To the best of our knowledge, compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> exhibits the first decarboxylation reaction achieved only by Sm(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>, 2,5-pydc and piperazine reactants using the hydrothermal method. This and other similar studies  support that hydrothermal synthesis may provide a simple, clean and economic method for preparing novel and unpredictable CPs and MOFs.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In this study, we chose the ligand 2,5-pydc because of its aforementioned features. Consequently we can report the synthesis and crystal structure of a novel samarium(III) coordination polymer, [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  (1), with an unprecedented coordination mode of 2,5-pydc. The thermal stability and luminescence property of compound 1 is also presented. To the best of our knowledge, compound 1 exhibits the first decarboxylation reaction achieved only by Sm(NO3)3, 2,5-pydc and piperazine reactants using the hydrothermal method. This and other similar studies  support that hydrothermal synthesis may provide a simple, clean and economic method for preparing novel and unpredictable CPs and MOFs.

<ce:section-title id="st010">Experimental</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st015">Materials and methods</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0015" view="all">Sm(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid and piperazine were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. The hydrothermal synthesis was carried out in 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL PTFE-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. IR spectra were measured with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet IS10 Model FT-IR spectrophotometer using the ATR method with a resolution of 4<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> at room temperature and a scan number of 32 in the solid phase and for the region 4000–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. A Thermo Flash 2000 CHNS Elemental Analyzer was used for elemental analysis. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) was conducted in a nitrogen atmosphere with Perkin Elmer Pyris Diamond TG/DTA equipment at a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>. Luminescence measurement was performed with a Xenon flash lamp based Varian/Agilent CARY Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer with a spectral resolution of about 5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm. A Rigaku Miniflex system with Cu Kα radiation (<ce:italic>λ</ce:italic>
<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>1.54059<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å) was used for the PXRD studies.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Experimental

Materials and methods

Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O, 2,5-pyridinedicarboxylic acid and piperazine were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. The hydrothermal synthesis was carried out in 23mL PTFE-lined stainless steel containers under autogenous pressure. IR spectra were measured with a Thermo Scientific Nicolet IS10 Model FT-IR spectrophotometer using the ATR method with a resolution of 4cm-1 at room temperature and a scan number of 32 in the solid phase and for the region 4000-400cm-1. A Thermo Flash 2000 CHNS Elemental Analyzer was used for elemental analysis. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) was conducted in a nitrogen atmosphere with Perkin Elmer Pyris Diamond TG/DTA equipment at a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1. Luminescence measurement was performed with a Xenon flash lamp based Varian/Agilent CARY Eclipse fluorescence spectrophotometer with a spectral resolution of about 5nm. A Rigaku Miniflex system with Cu Kα radiation (λ =1.54059Å) was used for the PXRD studies.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st020">Synthesis of the coordination polymer</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0020" view="all">All the starting materials were used directly without further purification. A mixture of Sm(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.134<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), pyridine 2,5-dicarboxylic acid (0.153<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.9<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), piperazine (0.027<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 0.3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL, 278<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol) in the mole ratio 1.00:3.00:1.00:927 was sealed in a 23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C for 72<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, and bright yellow colored crystals were obtained. The heterogeneous solution was separated from the solid phase, the crystals washed with water and dried at room temperature. Yield: 81% based on Sm. Initial pH; 1.90, final pH; 3.40. The coordination polymer is insoluble in common solvents (ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, etc.) and water. <ce:italic>Anal</ce:italic>. Calcd. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">9</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>Sm: C, 34.24; H, 1.98; N, 6.15. Found: C, 33.95; H, 1.71; N, 5.62%. IR data (cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>): 3478(w), 1660(m), 1566(s), 1392(s), 1361(s), 1033(m), 820(m), 769(s), 695(s), 505(s), 429(m).</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of the coordination polymer

All the starting materials were used directly without further purification. A mixture of Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.134g, 0.3mmol), pyridine 2,5-dicarboxylic acid (0.153g, 0.9mmol), piperazine (0.027g, 0.3mmol) and H2O (5mL, 278mmol) in the mole ratio 1.00:3.00:1.00:927 was sealed in a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160°C for 72h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 20°Ch-1, and bright yellow colored crystals were obtained. The heterogeneous solution was separated from the solid phase, the crystals washed with water and dried at room temperature. Yield: 81% based on Sm. Initial pH; 1.90, final pH; 3.40. The coordination polymer is insoluble in common solvents (ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, etc.) and water. Anal. Calcd. for C13H9N2O7Sm: C, 34.24; H, 1.98; N, 6.15. Found: C, 33.95; H, 1.71; N, 5.62%. IR data (cm-1): 3478(w), 1660(m), 1566(s), 1392(s), 1361(s), 1033(m), 820(m), 769(s), 695(s), 505(s), 429(m).

elements.clean_text:
X-ray structure determination

The crystallographic data for 1 were collected with a Bruker AXS APEX CCD diffractometer equipped with a rotation anode at 296(2)K using graphite monochromated Mo Kα radiation (λ =0.71073Å). Diffraction data were collected over the full sphere and were corrected for absorption. The data reduction was performed with the Bruker SMART  program package. A structure solution was found with the shelxs-97  package using the direct methods and was refined with shelxl-97  against F 2 using first isotropic and then anisotropic thermal parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. Hydrogen atoms were added to the structure model in calculated positions. Geometric calculations were performed with platon .

<ce:section-title id="st030">Results and discussion</ce:section-title><ce:section-title id="st035">Crystal structure of [Sm(pic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pydc)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">.</ce:inf> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>)</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0030" view="all">The crystallographic data and the corresponding selected bond lengths and angles of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are given in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0005"></ce:float-anchor>
<ce:float-anchor refid="t0010"></ce:float-anchor>, respectively. The Sm(III) ion is surrounded by four pydc and two pic ligands, as well as one water molecule. As shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0005"></ce:float-anchor>, each Sm(III) center is eight-coordinated by four O atoms from four different pydc ligands, two O atoms from pic, one N atom from pydc and an O atom from one coordinated water molecule, forming a square antiprismatic coordination geometry (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0010"></ce:float-anchor>a): O1–N1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.654, O4–N1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.974, O4–O7<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.883, O7–O1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>3.041, O2–O3<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.935, O3–O5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.844, O6–O5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.922 and O5–O2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>=<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>2.974<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Muetterties and Wright, in their review  on high coordination numbers, classified eight-coordinate molecules into two groups in terms of energy: a low-energy set of structures (dodecahedron (DD), square antiprism (SAP) and bicapped trigonal prism), and a higher energy set (cube, hexagonal bipyramid, square prism, bicapped trigonal antiprism and bicapped trigonal prism). By far the largest numbers of reported structures are found for the DD and SAP geometries, many with chelating ligands. Often there are alternative chelation modes, and they noted that the preferred isomer will be determined by a delicate balance of a host of electronic, “bite-size”, steric, and packing effects. Generally, for small-bite bidentate ligands, the DD structure is more favorable. In our system, complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> preferred the SAP geometry, with a relatively large chelation bite angle.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Results and discussion

Crystal structure of [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  . (1)

The crystallographic data and the corresponding selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are given in   , respectively. The Sm(III) ion is surrounded by four pydc and two pic ligands, as well as one water molecule. As shown in  , each Sm(III) center is eight-coordinated by four O atoms from four different pydc ligands, two O atoms from pic, one N atom from pydc and an O atom from one coordinated water molecule, forming a square antiprismatic coordination geometry ( a): O1-N1=2.654, O4-N1=2.974, O4-O7=2.883, O7-O1=3.041, O2-O3=2.935, O3-O5=2.844, O6-O5=2.922 and O5-O2=2.974Å. Muetterties and Wright, in their review  on high coordination numbers, classified eight-coordinate molecules into two groups in terms of energy: a low-energy set of structures (dodecahedron (DD), square antiprism (SAP) and bicapped trigonal prism), and a higher energy set (cube, hexagonal bipyramid, square prism, bicapped trigonal antiprism and bicapped trigonal prism). By far the largest numbers of reported structures are found for the DD and SAP geometries, many with chelating ligands. Often there are alternative chelation modes, and they noted that the preferred isomer will be determined by a delicate balance of a host of electronic, "bite-size", steric, and packing effects. Generally, for small-bite bidentate ligands, the DD structure is more favorable. In our system, complex 1 preferred the SAP geometry, with a relatively large chelation bite angle.

<ce:para id="p0035" view="all">In complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, one pydc anion takes three coordination modes (b). In the first mode, one carboxylate group adopts the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">2</ce:sup>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> bridging mode. In the second mode, the oxygen atom of a carboxylate group and the nitrogen atom of pyridine adopt the <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>-<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> chelating mode and the other oxygen atom of a carboxylate group is <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup>:<ce:italic>η</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">1</ce:sup> bridging as a third mode. The whole pydc ligand acts as a <ce:italic>μ</ce:italic>
<ce:sup loc="post">4</ce:sup>-bridge to link four different rare earth Sm(III) ions in adjacent chains, resulting in a three-dimensional network structure (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0015"></ce:float-anchor>). One pydc ligand chelates a Sm(III) ion via nitrogen and oxygen atoms while an O atom of the para-carboxylate bridges to a second Sm(III) ion. The two pic ligands bridge two Sm(III) ions, while two pydc ligands bridge simultaneously another two Sm ions via the nitrogen and one oxygen atom of one carboxylate group of pydc and the other oxygen atom of a carboxylate group to another Sm(III) ion. Thereby these bridging structures generate a 3D chain structure with neighboring Sm⋯Sm distances of 4.520 and 7.916<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The bond distances around the Sm(III) ion are in the range 2.327(2)–2.634(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, and the Sm-N distance is 2.634(2)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. Two of the four bridging Sm(1)–O distances are significantly shorter [Sm(1)–O(2) 2.327(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Sm(1)–O(6) 2.384(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å] than Sm(1)–O(3) 2.407 (3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å and Sm(1)–O(5) 2.396 (3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which are bridging the neighboring Sm(III) ion. In addition to that, other coordinated carboxylate oxygen to Sm distances are longer than former bonds: Sm(1)–O(4) 2.460(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, Sm(1)–O(1) 2.458(3)<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. The water oxygen coordinated to Sm has a bond length of 2.422<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å. These Sm–O distances are also comparable to those in related Sm(III)-carboxylates . Sm–N bond length value is 2.634<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>Å, which is similar to those observed for eight coordinate Sm(III) complexes with nitrogen donor ligands . The O–Sm–O and N–Sm–O angles are in the ranges 69.47(6)–149.13(6)° and 62.71(6)–146.88(7)°, respectively ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text: In complex 1, one pydc anion takes three coordination modes (b). In the first mode, one carboxylate group adopts the μ 2-η 1:η 1 bridging mode. In the second mode, the oxygen atom of a carboxylate group and the nitrogen atom of pyridine adopt the μ 1-η 1:η 1 chelating mode and the other oxygen atom of a carboxylate group is μ 1:η 1 bridging as a third mode. The whole pydc ligand acts as a μ 4-bridge to link four different rare earth Sm(III) ions in adjacent chains, resulting in a three-dimensional network structure ( ). One pydc ligand chelates a Sm(III) ion via nitrogen and oxygen atoms while an O atom of the para-carboxylate bridges to a second Sm(III) ion. The two pic ligands bridge two Sm(III) ions, while two pydc ligands bridge simultaneously another two Sm ions via the nitrogen and one oxygen atom of one carboxylate group of pydc and the other oxygen atom of a carboxylate group to another Sm(III) ion. Thereby these bridging structures generate a 3D chain structure with neighboring Sm⋯Sm distances of 4.520 and 7.916Å. The bond distances around the Sm(III) ion are in the range 2.327(2)-2.634(2)Å, and the Sm-N distance is 2.634(2)Å. Two of the four bridging Sm(1)-O distances are significantly shorter [Sm(1)-O(2) 2.327(3)Å, Sm(1)-O(6) 2.384(3)Å] than Sm(1)-O(3) 2.407 (3)Å and Sm(1)-O(5) 2.396 (3)Å, which are bridging the neighboring Sm(III) ion. In addition to that, other coordinated carboxylate oxygen to Sm distances are longer than former bonds: Sm(1)-O(4) 2.460(3)Å, Sm(1)-O(1) 2.458(3)Å. The water oxygen coordinated to Sm has a bond length of 2.422Å. These Sm-O distances are also comparable to those in related Sm(III)-carboxylates . Sm-N bond length value is 2.634Å, which is similar to those observed for eight coordinate Sm(III) complexes with nitrogen donor ligands . The O-Sm-O and N-Sm-O angles are in the ranges 69.47(6)-149.13(6)° and 62.71(6)-146.88(7)°, respectively ().

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st040">IR spectra</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0040" view="all">In the FT-infrared spectra, the ligand 2,5-pydc shows stretching bands attributed to <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H), <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O), <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>N) and <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(C<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H) at 3473, 1737, 1598 and 1120<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, respectively (). FT-IR spectrum of the complex displays a broad absorption band at about 3478<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> for the stretching vibrations of <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(O<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>H) groups  engaged in hydrogen bonds (O–H vibrations of water molecules). The C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching frequency of the ligand appeared at 1737<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> as the strongest absorption in the IR spectrum. After coordination, the C<ce:glyph name="dbnd"></ce:glyph>O stretching frequency of the complex shifted to 1660<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, indicating that the oxygen atoms in the carbonyl group were also coordinated to samarium ions . The remarkable changes observed in the 900–400<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> region for the complex are attributed to the coordination of the ligands to the metal. The appearance of <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Sm<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>O) bands at 722–650 and 526–592<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> can be attributed to the carbonyl and carboxylate oxygen atoms , respectively. These bands support the chelation through the O atoms. A new band, having very strong intensity at 505<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>cm<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup>, can be assigned to the <ce:italic>ν</ce:italic>(Sm<ce:glyph name="sbnd"></ce:glyph>N)  stretching vibration. This band supports chelation through the N atoms of the 2,5-pydc ligands ().</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
IR spectra

In the FT-infrared spectra, the ligand 2,5-pydc shows stretching bands attributed to ν(OH), ν(CO), ν(CN) and ν(CH) at 3473, 1737, 1598 and 1120cm-1, respectively (). FT-IR spectrum of the complex displays a broad absorption band at about 3478cm-1 for the stretching vibrations of ν(OH) groups  engaged in hydrogen bonds (O-H vibrations of water molecules). The CO stretching frequency of the ligand appeared at 1737cm-1 as the strongest absorption in the IR spectrum. After coordination, the CO stretching frequency of the complex shifted to 1660cm-1, indicating that the oxygen atoms in the carbonyl group were also coordinated to samarium ions . The remarkable changes observed in the 900-400cm-1 region for the complex are attributed to the coordination of the ligands to the metal. The appearance of ν(SmO) bands at 722-650 and 526-592cm-1 can be attributed to the carbonyl and carboxylate oxygen atoms , respectively. These bands support the chelation through the O atoms. A new band, having very strong intensity at 505cm-1, can be assigned to the ν(SmN)  stretching vibration. This band supports chelation through the N atoms of the 2,5-pydc ligands ().

<ce:section-title id="st045">Thermal stability</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0045" view="all">It is well known that lanthanide ions have a high coordination number, and this feature may cause structural flexibility and increase thermodynamic stability . TG analysis supported the thermal stability of the coordination polymer (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0020"></ce:float-anchor>). It was performed in the temperature range 50–800<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C under a N<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> atmosphere at 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>atm with a heating rate of 10<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min<ce:sup loc="post">−1</ce:sup> on a Perkin Elmer Diamond TG/DTA. The compound is thermally stable up to ∼300<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C. Above this temperature, the TG curve exhibits two weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 4.08%, between 298 and 340<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, is attributable to the loss of a coordinating water molecule in the formula unit (calculated: 3.95%). The next significant weight loss of 62.96%, which occurred from 350 to 545<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C, corresponds to the decomposition of the 2,5-pydc and picolinic ligands (calculated: 63.37%). The remaining weight of 32.96% corresponds to the final product, Sm<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf> percentage (32.68%). The thermal results fundamentally agree with the structure of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, and the observed thermal behavior reflects the structural features.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Thermal stability

It is well known that lanthanide ions have a high coordination number, and this feature may cause structural flexibility and increase thermodynamic stability . TG analysis supported the thermal stability of the coordination polymer ( ). It was performed in the temperature range 50-800°C under a N2 atmosphere at 1atm with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 on a Perkin Elmer Diamond TG/DTA. The compound is thermally stable up to ~300°C. Above this temperature, the TG curve exhibits two weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 4.08%, between 298 and 340°C, is attributable to the loss of a coordinating water molecule in the formula unit (calculated: 3.95%). The next significant weight loss of 62.96%, which occurred from 350 to 545°C, corresponds to the decomposition of the 2,5-pydc and picolinic ligands (calculated: 63.37%). The remaining weight of 32.96% corresponds to the final product, Sm2O3 percentage (32.68%). The thermal results fundamentally agree with the structure of 1, and the observed thermal behavior reflects the structural features.

</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0050" view="all">In order to check the phase purity of compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>, the sample was measured by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) at room temperature. The experimental powder XRD pattern of the bulk product (
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0025"></ce:float-anchor>) is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of the single-crystal structure (), indicating the high purity of the synthesized sample. Also, the elemental analysis was consistent with the theoretical values. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and experimental patterns was due to the variation in the preferred orientation of the powder sample during collection of the experimental PXRD data. The crystallinity data of the compound <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> are given in the .</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Phase and purity of the compound 1 

In order to check the phase purity of compound 1, the sample was measured by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) at room temperature. The experimental powder XRD pattern of the bulk product ( ) is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of the single-crystal structure (), indicating the high purity of the synthesized sample. Also, the elemental analysis was consistent with the theoretical values. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and experimental patterns was due to the variation in the preferred orientation of the powder sample during collection of the experimental PXRD data. The crystallinity data of the compound 1 are given in the .

<ce:section-title id="st055">Luminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The luminescent properties of the ligand and the synthesized polymeric metal complex were investigated in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>. The luminescent spectrum of pure 2,5-pydc was measured under the same conditions in order to understand the nature of the luminescence of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For pure 2,5-pydc, the emission spectrum shows three primary and intense emission bands with the maximum wavelengths of 215, 232 and 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm under excitation at 190<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . In contrast, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows only one emission band in the blue region with a maximum wavelength of 498<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation with a wavelength of 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, assigned to the typical f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion in the phosphorescence region. When compared with previous studies, the emission broad bands of Ln-complexes with aromatic pyridine carboxylate ligands have also been between 495 and 650<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for Sm(III), Dy(III), Eu(III) and Tb(III) . The 2,5-pydc ligand has no emission in the visible region, but when it is coordinated to a samarium center, observing a blue luminescence emission is supported by the bonding. This lower energy band should probably be assigned to the LMCT transition (charge transfer from the ligand to the samarium metal) . [Sm(pic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pydc)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) can be considered as a potentially useful photoactive materials.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

The luminescent properties of the ligand and the synthesized polymeric metal complex were investigated in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in  . The luminescent spectrum of pure 2,5-pydc was measured under the same conditions in order to understand the nature of the luminescence of complex 1. For pure 2,5-pydc, the emission spectrum shows three primary and intense emission bands with the maximum wavelengths of 215, 232 and 260nm under excitation at 190nm . In contrast, 1 shows only one emission band in the blue region with a maximum wavelength of 498nm upon excitation with a wavelength of 250nm, assigned to the typical f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion in the phosphorescence region. When compared with previous studies, the emission broad bands of Ln-complexes with aromatic pyridine carboxylate ligands have also been between 495 and 650nm for Sm(III), Dy(III), Eu(III) and Tb(III) . The 2,5-pydc ligand has no emission in the visible region, but when it is coordinated to a samarium center, observing a blue luminescence emission is supported by the bonding. This lower energy band should probably be assigned to the LMCT transition (charge transfer from the ligand to the samarium metal) . [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  (1) can be considered as a potentially useful photoactive materials.

elements.content: <ce:section-title id="st060">Conclusion</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0060" view="all">In summary, we have synthesized a novel Sm(III) coordination polymer from the reaction mixture of Sm(NO<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>·6H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, 2,5-pydcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, piperazine and H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O by a hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized this polymer for the first time. We used 2,5-pydcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> as a starting ligand, but in situ hydrothermal decarboxylation reaction was observed and picolinic acid was produced. The X-ray results showed that 2,5-pydcH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf> and picolinic acid coordinated separately to the samarium center, giving an unprecedented coordination polymer containing a heteroleptic metal complex. Different reaction temperatures, stoichiometry and pH lead to a dramatic structural change in the reaction product. In addition, the metal complex polymer exhibits good thermal stability and photoluminescence emission in the solid state in the phosphorescence region.</ce:para>
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have synthesized a novel Sm(III) coordination polymer from the reaction mixture of Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O, 2,5-pydcH2, piperazine and H2O by a hydrothermal reaction and structurally characterized this polymer for the first time. We used 2,5-pydcH2 as a starting ligand, but in situ hydrothermal decarboxylation reaction was observed and picolinic acid was produced. The X-ray results showed that 2,5-pydcH2 and picolinic acid coordinated separately to the samarium center, giving an unprecedented coordination polymer containing a heteroleptic metal complex. Different reaction temperatures, stoichiometry and pH lead to a dramatic structural change in the reaction product. In addition, the metal complex polymer exhibits good thermal stability and photoluminescence emission in the solid state in the phosphorescence region.

Synthesis of the coordination polymer

All the starting materials were used directly without further purification. A mixture of Sm(NO3)3⋅6H2O (0.134g, 0.3mmol), pyridine 2,5-dicarboxylic acid (0.153g, 0.9mmol), piperazine (0.027g, 0.3mmol) and H2O (5mL, 278mmol) in the mole ratio 1.00:3.00:1.00:927 was sealed in a 23mL Teflon reactor and kept under autogenous pressure at 160°C for 72h. The mixture was cooled to room temperature at a rate of 20°Ch-1, and bright yellow colored crystals were obtained. The heterogeneous solution was separated from the solid phase, the crystals washed with water and dried at room temperature. Yield: 81% based on Sm. Initial pH; 1.90, final pH; 3.40. The coordination polymer is insoluble in common solvents (ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, etc.) and water. Anal. Calcd. for C13H9N2O7Sm: C, 34.24; H, 1.98; N, 6.15. Found: C, 33.95; H, 1.71; N, 5.62%. IR data (cm-1): 3478(w), 1660(m), 1566(s), 1392(s), 1361(s), 1033(m), 820(m), 769(s), 695(s), 505(s), 429(m).

other properties: insoluble in common solvents (ethanol, methanol, acetonitrile, etc.) and water

Graphical abstract

A novel 3D coordination polymer was synthesized in a hydrothermal reaction. The thermal stability and photoluminescence properties of complex have been investigated.     

Abstract

A novel three dimensional (3D) coordination polymer [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  (pydc=pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylate, Hpic=picolinic acid) (1) has been synthesized hydrothermally and characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR, TG/DTA, single-crystal X-ray diffraction analysis and powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD). This compound crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c with cell parameters a =9.3041(13)Å, b =14.216(2)Å, c =10.5401(15)Å, V =1387.72(30)Å3 and Z =4. Complex 1 has a distinct 3D open-framework architecture due to the presence of picolinic ligands, which are converted from 2,5-pydc ligands by in-situ decarboxylation under the hydrothermal conditions. The compound exhibits strong luminescent emissions because of the f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion at room temperature. According to TGA/DTA analysis, the coordination polymer is thermally stable up to ~300°C.

Results and discussion

Crystal structure of [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  . (1)

The crystallographic data and the corresponding selected bond lengths and angles of 1 are given in   , respectively. The Sm(III) ion is surrounded by four pydc and two pic ligands, as well as one water molecule. As shown in  , each Sm(III) center is eight-coordinated by four O atoms from four different pydc ligands, two O atoms from pic, one N atom from pydc and an O atom from one coordinated water molecule, forming a square antiprismatic coordination geometry ( a): O1-N1=2.654, O4-N1=2.974, O4-O7=2.883, O7-O1=3.041, O2-O3=2.935, O3-O5=2.844, O6-O5=2.922 and O5-O2=2.974Å. Muetterties and Wright, in their review  on high coordination numbers, classified eight-coordinate molecules into two groups in terms of energy: a low-energy set of structures (dodecahedron (DD), square antiprism (SAP) and bicapped trigonal prism), and a higher energy set (cube, hexagonal bipyramid, square prism, bicapped trigonal antiprism and bicapped trigonal prism). By far the largest numbers of reported structures are found for the DD and SAP geometries, many with chelating ligands. Often there are alternative chelation modes, and they noted that the preferred isomer will be determined by a delicate balance of a host of electronic, "bite-size", steric, and packing effects. Generally, for small-bite bidentate ligands, the DD structure is more favorable. In our system, complex 1 preferred the SAP geometry, with a relatively large chelation bite angle.

In complex 1, one pydc anion takes three coordination modes (b). In the first mode, one carboxylate group adopts the μ 2-η 1:η 1 bridging mode. In the second mode, the oxygen atom of a carboxylate group and the nitrogen atom of pyridine adopt the μ 1-η 1:η 1 chelating mode and the other oxygen atom of a carboxylate group is μ 1:η 1 bridging as a third mode. The whole pydc ligand acts as a μ 4-bridge to link four different rare earth Sm(III) ions in adjacent chains, resulting in a three-dimensional network structure ( ). One pydc ligand chelates a Sm(III) ion via nitrogen and oxygen atoms while an O atom of the para-carboxylate bridges to a second Sm(III) ion. The two pic ligands bridge two Sm(III) ions, while two pydc ligands bridge simultaneously another two Sm ions via the nitrogen and one oxygen atom of one carboxylate group of pydc and the other oxygen atom of a carboxylate group to another Sm(III) ion. Thereby these bridging structures generate a 3D chain structure with neighboring Sm⋯Sm distances of 4.520 and 7.916Å. The bond distances around the Sm(III) ion are in the range 2.327(2)-2.634(2)Å, and the Sm-N distance is 2.634(2)Å. Two of the four bridging Sm(1)-O distances are significantly shorter [Sm(1)-O(2) 2.327(3)Å, Sm(1)-O(6) 2.384(3)Å] than Sm(1)-O(3) 2.407 (3)Å and Sm(1)-O(5) 2.396 (3)Å, which are bridging the neighboring Sm(III) ion. In addition to that, other coordinated carboxylate oxygen to Sm distances are longer than former bonds: Sm(1)-O(4) 2.460(3)Å, Sm(1)-O(1) 2.458(3)Å. The water oxygen coordinated to Sm has a bond length of 2.422Å. These Sm-O distances are also comparable to those in related Sm(III)-carboxylates . Sm-N bond length value is 2.634Å, which is similar to those observed for eight coordinate Sm(III) complexes with nitrogen donor ligands . The O-Sm-O and N-Sm-O angles are in the ranges 69.47(6)-149.13(6)° and 62.71(6)-146.88(7)°, respectively ().

IR spectra

In the FT-infrared spectra, the ligand 2,5-pydc shows stretching bands attributed to ν(OH), ν(CO), ν(CN) and ν(CH) at 3473, 1737, 1598 and 1120cm-1, respectively (). FT-IR spectrum of the complex displays a broad absorption band at about 3478cm-1 for the stretching vibrations of ν(OH) groups  engaged in hydrogen bonds (O-H vibrations of water molecules). The CO stretching frequency of the ligand appeared at 1737cm-1 as the strongest absorption in the IR spectrum. After coordination, the CO stretching frequency of the complex shifted to 1660cm-1, indicating that the oxygen atoms in the carbonyl group were also coordinated to samarium ions . The remarkable changes observed in the 900-400cm-1 region for the complex are attributed to the coordination of the ligands to the metal. The appearance of ν(SmO) bands at 722-650 and 526-592cm-1 can be attributed to the carbonyl and carboxylate oxygen atoms , respectively. These bands support the chelation through the O atoms. A new band, having very strong intensity at 505cm-1, can be assigned to the ν(SmN)  stretching vibration. This band supports chelation through the N atoms of the 2,5-pydc ligands ().

Thermal stability

It is well known that lanthanide ions have a high coordination number, and this feature may cause structural flexibility and increase thermodynamic stability . TG analysis supported the thermal stability of the coordination polymer ( ). It was performed in the temperature range 50-800°C under a N2 atmosphere at 1atm with a heating rate of 10°Cmin-1 on a Perkin Elmer Diamond TG/DTA. The compound is thermally stable up to ~300°C. Above this temperature, the TG curve exhibits two weight loss steps. The first weight loss of 4.08%, between 298 and 340°C, is attributable to the loss of a coordinating water molecule in the formula unit (calculated: 3.95%). The next significant weight loss of 62.96%, which occurred from 350 to 545°C, corresponds to the decomposition of the 2,5-pydc and picolinic ligands (calculated: 63.37%). The remaining weight of 32.96% corresponds to the final product, Sm2O3 percentage (32.68%). The thermal results fundamentally agree with the structure of 1, and the observed thermal behavior reflects the structural features.

Phase and purity of the compound 1 

In order to check the phase purity of compound 1, the sample was measured by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) at room temperature. The experimental powder XRD pattern of the bulk product ( ) is in good agreement with the simulated one on the basis of the single-crystal structure (), indicating the high purity of the synthesized sample. Also, the elemental analysis was consistent with the theoretical values. The difference in reflection intensities between the simulated and experimental patterns was due to the variation in the preferred orientation of the powder sample during collection of the experimental PXRD data. The crystallinity data of the compound 1 are given in the .

<ce:section-title id="st055">Luminescence properties</ce:section-title><ce:para id="p0055" view="all">The luminescent properties of the ligand and the synthesized polymeric metal complex were investigated in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in 
<ce:float-anchor refid="f0030"></ce:float-anchor>. The luminescent spectrum of pure 2,5-pydc was measured under the same conditions in order to understand the nature of the luminescence of complex <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. For pure 2,5-pydc, the emission spectrum shows three primary and intense emission bands with the maximum wavelengths of 215, 232 and 260<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm under excitation at 190<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm . In contrast, <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> shows only one emission band in the blue region with a maximum wavelength of 498<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm upon excitation with a wavelength of 250<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm, assigned to the typical f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion in the phosphorescence region. When compared with previous studies, the emission broad bands of Ln-complexes with aromatic pyridine carboxylate ligands have also been between 495 and 650<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>nm for Sm(III), Dy(III), Eu(III) and Tb(III) . The 2,5-pydc ligand has no emission in the visible region, but when it is coordinated to a samarium center, observing a blue luminescence emission is supported by the bonding. This lower energy band should probably be assigned to the LMCT transition (charge transfer from the ligand to the samarium metal) . [Sm(pic)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>(pydc)<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>(H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O)]<ce:italic>
<ce:inf loc="post">n</ce:inf>
</ce:italic> (<ce:bold>1</ce:bold>) can be considered as a potentially useful photoactive materials.</ce:para>
cln_elements.clean_text:
Luminescence properties

The luminescent properties of the ligand and the synthesized polymeric metal complex were investigated in the solid state at room temperature, as shown in  . The luminescent spectrum of pure 2,5-pydc was measured under the same conditions in order to understand the nature of the luminescence of complex 1. For pure 2,5-pydc, the emission spectrum shows three primary and intense emission bands with the maximum wavelengths of 215, 232 and 260nm under excitation at 190nm . In contrast, 1 shows only one emission band in the blue region with a maximum wavelength of 498nm upon excitation with a wavelength of 250nm, assigned to the typical f-f transitions of the Sm(III) ion in the phosphorescence region. When compared with previous studies, the emission broad bands of Ln-complexes with aromatic pyridine carboxylate ligands have also been between 495 and 650nm for Sm(III), Dy(III), Eu(III) and Tb(III) . The 2,5-pydc ligand has no emission in the visible region, but when it is coordinated to a samarium center, observing a blue luminescence emission is supported by the bonding. This lower energy band should probably be assigned to the LMCT transition (charge transfer from the ligand to the samarium metal) . [Sm(pic)2(pydc)4(H2O)] n  (1) can be considered as a potentially useful photoactive materials.
